results.title: Victoria's Favourite Things. Segment 11
results.brief_description: The results of July 2004’s Open House weekend program ‘Victoria’s Favourite Things’. This segment features Kenton from Nundawading who just loves life and the state of Victoria; a woman who has four deeply meaningful Rings; Nairee and Michelle from Traralgon tell us about ‘my dog Oscar’; and Adrian from Brunswick has a passion for Melbourne’s live music scene.

results.title: Victoria's Favourite Things. Segment 10
results.brief_description: The results of July 2004’s Open House weekend program ‘Victoria’s Favourite Things’. This segment features Michael who shares his love of imagination; Ivan and Luke really like Dinosaurs; Madelaine from Clayton is a BIG fan of Horses; and Michelle from Frankston’s favourite thing is absolutely the beach.

results.title: Victoria's Favourite Things. Segment 1
results.brief_description: The results of July 2004’s Open House weekend program ‘Victoria’s Favourite Things’. This segment features Norma from Swan Hill talking about a Mallee root; Alex from Melbourne discusses 19th century literature; Adam Elliott is still thrilled by his Oscar; Lewis loves the Spy Kids movies; Alfred of Reservoir tells us that retirement is his favourite thing and a visitor from Hong Kong bursts into song!

results.title: Victoria's favourite things
results.brief_description:
Check out what people brought to ACMI for July 2004’s Open House weekend program ‘Victoria’s Favourite Things’.
Recorded live in ACMI’s Screen Pit, the event was modelled on a 1960’s variety show and includes songs, stories, bad jokes and some really interesting stuff.

results.title: Vicki (TEFC)
results.brief_description: A documentary approach to the problems encountered by Vicki, born without arms, and her ways of coping with work, family and her desires for marriage and a family. Produced for television as an introduction to social services available from Government agencies.

results.title: Vicki
results.creator_credit: Suzanne Baker, Film Australia and Bob Kingsbury
results.brief_description: Vicki is born without arms and this documentary looks at her approach to life and her ways of coping with work, her future marriage, her desire for children and the way people treat her. One of a series of films originally created for a day-time television discussion panel which was designed to alert the public to the range of social services available from Government and other agencies. Suitable for secondary school level.

results.title: Vibrato
results.creator_credit: Gerald Hagner, Gerald Hagner Productions and Ohio Arts Council
results.brief_description: Using camera movement, multiple images, and synchronised music to transform nature into a statement of beauty, Gerald Hagner’s award winning film presents a stunning impression of the Appalachian mountains. Without narration. Photographed by Gerald Hagner alone in the Appalachian Mountains, Ohio and synchronised music by Art Kempel.

results.title: VFX in Thor: Ragnarok
results.brief_description: Adelaide-based VFX company Rising Sun Pictures were entrusted with a pivotal moment in Thor: Ragnaork, where Tessa Thompson’s character recounts the fatal encounter between the Valkyrie warriors and the Asgardian Goddess of Death, Hela (Cate Blanchett).

constellations_primary.name: Superhero special effects
constellations_primary.description: VFX talent isn't limited to just one studio that makes superhero blockbusters.

results.description: One of Thor: Ragnarok‘s (2017) most heartbreaking moments also happens to be one of its most beautiful. Adelaide-based visual effects company Rising Sun Pictures were entrusted with a pivotal moment where Tessa Thompson’s character recounts the fatal encounter between the Valkyrie warriors and the Asgardian Goddess of Death, Hela. The flashback plays out in artful slow motion, with the carnage captured under glittering light thanks to an innovative lighting rig designed by Satellite Lab to create high-speed changes in lighting. Rising Sun Pictures have built an international reputation for their expertise in slow motion visual effects, which were also seen in X-Men: Days of Future Past (2014).
description_for_label: One of Thor: Ragnarok‘s most heartbreaking moments is also one of its most beautiful. Adelaide-based VFX company Rising Sun Pictures created the pivotal moment where Tessa Thompson’s character recounts the fatal encounter between the Valkyrie warriors and the Asgardian Goddess of Death, Hela. The flashback happens in artful slow motion, with the carnage captured under glittering light thanks to an innovative lighting rig designed by Satellite Lab to create high-speed changes in lighting. Rising Sun Pictures also demonstrated their expertise in slow-motion VFX in X-Men: Days of Future Past.

details.label: Curatorial section
display_values: The Story of the Moving Image → Moving Worlds → MW-06. Visual Effects → MW-06-AV04

results.title: VFX in JoJo Rabbit
results.credit_line:
VFX Supervisor: Brendan Seals
Courtesy Luma Pictures and Fox Searchlight Pictures
results.brief_description: Visual effects studio Luma Pictures helped Taika Waititi realise his creative vision for Jojo Rabbit by replacing contemporary elements in scenes with period-accurate ones that represent WWII Germany.

constellations_primary.name: Undercutting extremism with absurdity
constellations_primary.description: Taika Waititi's satirical performance as Adolf Hitler in Jojo Rabbit connects to a number of other portrayals that includes ill-fated (and conceived) TV shows, memes, high camp and cinema classics.

results.description: The world through a child’s eyes is a unique thing, even more so when that child is created by Academy Award-nominee Taika Waititi. Visual effects studio Luma Pictures helped Waititi realise his creative vision for Jojo Rabbit. Luma Pictures took street scenes filmed in the present-day Czech Republic and made them more historically appropriate for World War II Germany. Removing contemporary elements and replacing them with period-accurate ones is subtle work, but it helps weave the tapestry of Jojo’s reality: both real and imagined.
description_for_label: The world through a child’s eyes is a unique thing, even more so when that child is created by Academy Award-nominee Taika Waititi. Visual effects studio Luma Pictures helped Waititi realise his creative vision for Jojo Rabbit. Luma Pictures took street scenes filmed in the present-day Czech Republic and made them more historically appropriate for World War II Germany. Removing contemporary elements and replacing them with period-accurate ones is subtle work, but it helps weave the tapestry of Jojo’s reality: both real and imagined.
results.credit_line_for_label:
VFX Supervisor: Brendan Seals
Courtesy Luma Pictures and Fox Searchlight Pictures

details.label: Curatorial section

results.title: VFX in American Gods
results.credit_line:
Title sequence creative director: Patrick Clair
Courtesy Fremantle
results.brief_description: A look at the acclaimed title sequence from American Gods, by VFX studio Antibody.

constellations_primary.name: The world's end
constellations_primary.description: For people of colour oppressed by systemic racism, genre stories about the end of the world and cosmological monsters can be used to re-examine race and the injustices faced in real life.

results.description: Growing up in a Catholic home, Patrick Clair was used to seeing religious iconography. Little did he know he would one day have the opportunity to merge and subvert it with his work at motion graphics studio Antibody, alongside Raoul Marks. Having redefined the art of opening credits during the peak TV era, American Gods (2017–present) saw the Antibody team mix religious and patriotic symbolism together for their most daring work yet as they brought the mythologies of Neil Gaiman’s source material to life.
description_for_label:
Growing up in a Catholic home, Patrick Clair was used to seeing religious iconography. Little did he know he would one day have the opportunity to merge and subvert it with his work at motion graphics studio Antibody, alongside Raoul Marks. Having redefined the art of opening credits during the peak TV era, American Gods (2017–present) saw the Antibody team mix religious and patriotic symbolism together for their most daring work yet as they brought the mythologies of Neil Gaiman’s source material to life.

No photography
